title: Documenting Structure
contents:
After a couple days focused on the infrastructure of this site, I finally got to post some content beside this Dev Log!
Specifically, I started a new collection of posts which will focus on how my digital edition of Terra Ignota is structured. The inaugural entry documents the high-level structure of the edition’s single TEI-XML file.
Future entries will drill down into specific elements in the schema and how I used them during mark-up and analysis.
Also fixed some typos and improved the navigation.
What It Took to Get Here
Clarifications
Clarify Structure of TEI DocumentUse distill::create_post() with collection parameter to create the collection and its first post at the same time
Add new collection to Nav
Write content for first post


Enhancements
Add Home to Nav

Typos
Typo in About#Xquery
Typo in Feedback Welcome

Typo in Dev Log’s description

Lessons Learned
None
Sometimes stuff just works!

title: Feedback Welcome!
description: I've added a couple different ways for you, gentle reader, to provide feedback on our voyage together.
contents:
GitHub Is Where We Live Now
These feedback methods all require a Github account, which has the following advantages:
it keeps all of the feedback in one place, within the project itself,
it provides me with robust tools to organize, respond to, and implement changes based on that feedback,
it provides you with robust tools to manage replies and notifications, and
I can give you proper credit when I implement or fix something based on your feedback.
If you need a new account, try the instructions here.
General Conversations
Via the GitHub Discussions page, you can start or join conversations about whatever aspects of this project strikes your fancy. Keep it civil and follow our code of conduct is all I ask.
A good place to start is our Meet & Greet thread. Drop by and introduce yourself!
Requesting Changes
You can request changes and updates via the GitHub Issues page. When creating an new issue, you will be offered a choice of three templates:
Analysis or Data Request: Use this to suggest an idea for a new analysis, or to request a CSV file I’m not currently providing.
Clarification Request: Use this to request a clarification, when I’ve been less than clear, perhaps, or when you’d like me to explain something at longer length.
Typo Report: Use this to help me fix typos anywhere on the site.
When in doubt, feel free to create a generic issue or to start a new discussion instead.
What It Took to Get Here:

Add a Code of Conduct to the repo

Turn on GitHub Discussions

Add three templates to GitHub Issues

Branch the code

Rename index page to about to move that content while preserving change history

Write pithier content for new index page

Create and merge Pull Request back to main branch
Lessons Learned
index page must have site: in yaml header
The distill package will complain about there being no listing page for your blog posts until it finds the site: distill::distill_website key in the yaml of the index page.
CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md now gets rendered
It didn’t before, and README.md still doesn’t. I added a rmarkdown yaml to it so that at least the text renders. Created this issue to track.

title: Hello World
description: Standing up the website and saying hello...
contents:
It’s time to stand up a little website to share the results of my explorations into “data ignota”, the digital edition I’ve been creating of Ada Palmer’s Terra Ignota series. This is that website.
Since the ship I’ve launched on that digital ocean is built from R, it makes sense to build this site from the same timber. After some research, I’ve decided to use the distill package as the primary tool, and to publish via Github Pages.
What It Took to Get Here

Create public repo at: https://github.com/syvwlch/Data-Ignota

Clone repo to R project (using Github Desktop, not R studio)

Create Distill blog within project

Add/update content

Build site & preview locally

Push to github

Setup github pages

Site is up at: https://syvwlch.github.io/Data-Ignota/

Add base_url: key to site.yml (used for RSS feed and share cards)
Lessons Learned
Always Be Knitting (your posts)
The distill package automatically builds web pages except for posts like this one. This is done to keep the build fast and to protect posts which might have dependencies from breaking later. So for posts it’s not enough to hit save, you have to reknit them on purpose.
